Aloha
from
Hawaii
the
Diamond Head
Beachcombers
After Mark Twain visited the Hawaiian Islands, he described the grass shacks, the horse and
sailboat travel, and the girls who would toss off their muu muus and jump into the water naked —
although, Iwain insists, he wasn't really looking. The American humorists sense of stateside
propriety may have kept him from looking, but it could also have been that he was kept busy
listening to the haunting and exotic music of the Islands.
In the days since Mark Twain's visit the grass shacks have been replaced by modern houses,
hotels and motels; the horses by U-Drive cars; and the girls have become a bit more modest.
The music. however. remains as magical as it ever was, creating pictures of exotic flowers,
The Diamond Head Beachcombers are Island troubadours who use Hawaiian guitars and strings
to portray Polynesian charm and develop a mood befitting tropic island romance. Working with
such popular and attractive melodies as To 1ou, sweetheart, Alond, song of the Islands, A Dong
of Old Hawaii and Lovely Hula Hands, the Beachcombers offer a musical tour of our newest
state that's complete and enchanting.
MIKE Gross
Recorded in New York City, April 1, 2 and 3, 1959. Recording Engineer: Bob Simpson.
